author: graymattr
title: The first (of hopefully many) Universal Monsters BrickHeadz!
review:
I don't own many BrickHeadz but I love the ones that I do and this is a clear favorite of mine.  I really enjoy the seasonal BrickHeadz.  This isn't marketed strictly as a seasonal set but given that a Frankenstein model is released in the fall, it's clearly timed right for the Halloween season.  And let me be the first to welcome Universal Studios to the Lego universe with this beginning set of Universal Monsters!  I abhor modern horror movies but the classics from Universal are great so I was excited to get this to go on my desk at work during the Halloween season.

This model was designed by Nina Koopman based on sketches from Lego graphic designers Chris Boven and Austin Carlson. 

This set comes in three bags within the box with the instructions and baseplate floating freely within.  There aren't too many pieces to quickly organize them before building if you like to do that.  The instructions are clear and the building process is quick like other BrickHeadz models.

I've seen some people complain about the monochromatic colors but I think it clearly depicts the monster from the Boris Karloff movies which were black and white.  There are pieces that are red, yellow, etc., inside the model that get covered by the outer layer of pieces.  I think the pearl silver studs were a great idea for the metal rods protruding from his neck.  The printed pieces for his suit jacket and forehead work well. 

This is a really good depiction of Karloff's character and because it's a BrickHeadz model, we don't need to get bothered by not being spot on.  As with all BrickHeads, the head takes up the majority of the completed model.

Other seasonal BrickHeadz sets have decorative mini-builds to accompany them, such as 40351 Halloween Ghost having a Jack-o-lantern, gravestone and such.  Because this isn't considered a "seasonal" set, I can cut it some slack.  I've seen a couple people give him a flower in one hand but I can't think of how else to spruce him up unless you wanted to add some pitchforks and torches.  ;-)

I want to note that my ratings are based on comparing this with the other BrickHeadz sets I have because I would rate them differently from standard Lego sets that have playable features.  If you like Halloween, monsters or film noir, I would highly recommend this set.  I think it's great.
